options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Really interesting perspective on English poetry because we studied through a lens of thinking about post-truth.
I learned how to close-read poetry, particularly in the context of the Victorian relationship to truth, and also improved my writing. We read a lot of great poems on a variety of topics.
This course has a great reading list and very good discussions, and Professor Brisman is amazing as always.
This course is a great survey of Victorian poetry, with Romantic poetry thrown in for context or comparison at times.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: 
a really interesting angle on victorian poetry. Focusing on mostly three major poets helped keep the course not too broad. 

Weaknesses: 
The syllabus was definitely too large. We would have several readings assigned and only have time to discuss one or two. Also it's a do-the-reading, come to class and talk about it and listen to the professor talk about it kind of class. Which isn't super engaging if you didn't have time to really deeply read every day or just didn't like the poem. 

Also I'm not sure if this is a strength or a weakness necessarily but the writing assignments were totally open-ended, in that there was not a prompt and very little guidance on what was expected, which was a little difficult to navigate. Professor Brisman is an acquired taste. I enjoyed his insights and anecdotes, but others might find them off-putting.

This course benefitted from the great variety of material, and the Professor's extensive knowledge of both the poetry and also writing in general, so that we could gain enjoyable insights of the poetry while improving our ability to close-read literature and our writing. The course always had a manageable workload, so that it was fun being able to show up to class each day with only a handful of poems and examine them at length.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This poem did not have any problems with virtual engagement. We always had a manageable workload and asked interesting questions of the poetry in each class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are very interested in Victorian poetry and have a lot of time to really commit to reading, yes. If not, you're going to be bored because a lot of the syllabus is really dense poetry that you can't really BS.

I would recommend this course to any student who wants to explore poetry. Whether these are first-encounters or the student taking their reading of poetry to the next level, this course allowed us to make the most of a lot of exciting and intriguing poems, which then bled into some profound political and philosophical conversations.
Yes, definitely. It's especially good after having taken Romantic Poetry.

This class is great if you want a survey of Victorian Lit, but the seminars are taught almost lecture-style in that students don't really speak a ton. Professor Brisman explains poems a lot via personal anecdote.
